skills.name: Drawing and interpreting line plots involving fractions (same denominator)
Drawing and interpreting line plots involving fractions with different denominators

explanations.A: Chloe and Gill both have pencils that are 4 3/4 inches long therefore there will be two crosses in the 4 3/4 column.
explanations.B: Count again, there is more than one person with a 4 3/4 inch pencil...
explanations.C: This is the total number of pencils that were measured. The question is asking how many students have a 4 3/4 inch pencil.
explanations.D: I think you have counted how many 5 1/4 inch pencils there are. We are looking for the number of 4 3/4 inch pencils...

explanations.A: There are no crosses in the 5 1/4 column yet, but can you count how many people in the table measured 5 1/4 inches?
explanations.B: Count again, there is more than one person with a 5 1/4 inch pencil...
explanations.C: Ann and Gill both have pencils that are 5 1/4 inches long therefore there will be two crosses in the 5 1/4 column.
explanations.D: This is the total number of pencils that were measured. The question is asking how many students have a 5 1/4 inch pencil.

explanations.A: There are no days with 2 inches of snowfall therefore there will be 0 crosses in the 2 column.
explanations.B: I think you may have counted the 2 2/4 inches. Have another look in the table, how many days had 2 inches of snowfall?
explanations.C: I think you may have counted the 2 1/4 inches. Have another look in the table, how many days had 2 inches of snowfall?
explanations.D: This is the total number of days where the snowfall was measured. The question is asking: on how many of these days was there 2 inches of snowfall?

explanations.A: There are no days with 2 inches of snowfall therefore there will be 0 crosses in the 2 column.
explanations.B: I think you may have counted the 2 1/2 inches. Have another look in the table, how many days had 2 inches of snowfall?
explanations.C: I think you may have counted all the measurements with 1/2. Have another look in the table, how many days had exactly 2 inches of snowfall?
explanations.D: This is the total number of days where the snowfall was measured. The question is asking: on how many of these days was there 2 inches of snowfall?

explanations.A: We have one 1 3/4 in the table and one cross in the 1 3/4 column so it's not this value. Look at which value has more crosses on the diagram compared to how many of it there are in the table...
explanations.B: There are three 2s in the table and three crosses in the 2s column therefore it's not this value. Look at which value has more crosses on the diagram compared to how many of it there are in the table...
explanations.C: There is only one 2 1/4 in the table but there are two crosses in the 2 1/4 column therefore this is the missing value!
explanations.D: There is one 2 2/4 in the table and one cross in the 2 2/4 column on the diagram so it's not this value. Look at which value has more crosses on the diagram compared to how many of it there are in the table...

explanations.A: We have one 1 3/4 in the table and one cross in the 1 3/4 column so it's not this value. Look at which value has more crosses on the diagram compared to how many of it there are in the table...
explanations.B: There are only two 2s in the table but there are three crosses in the 2 column so this is the missing value!
explanations.C: We have one 2 1/4 in the table and one cross in the 2 1/4 column so it's not this value. Look at which value has more crosses on the diagram compared to how many of it there are in the table...
explanations.D: There are two 2 2/4 measurements in the table and two crosses in the 2 2/4 column on the diagram so it's not this value. Look at which value has more crosses on the diagram compared to how many of it there are in the table...

explanations.A: This is how many days the mass of her school bag was 7 3/4 kg. Look at the 8 1/4kg column, how many crosses are there?
explanations.B: This is how many days her bag was 7 1/4kg or 8 2/4kg. Look at the 8 1/4kg column, how many crosses are there?
explanations.C: This is the total number of days the mass of Katie's school bag was measured. The question is asking on how many of these 9 days was the mass of her bag 8 1/4 kg...
explanations.D: There are three crosses in the 8 1/4 kg column in the line plot therefore this was the mass of her school bag for 3 days!

explanations.A: This is how many days the mass of her school bag was 7 1/4 kg. Look at the 7 3/4 kg column, how many crosses are there?
explanations.B: Double check which column you are looking at. Look at the 7 3/4 kg column, how many crosses are there?
explanations.C: There are two crosses in the 7 3/4 kg column in the line plot therefore this was the mass of her school bag for 2 days!
explanations.D: This is the total number of days the mass of Katie's school bag was measured. The question is asking on how many of these 8 days was the mass of her bag 7 3/4 kg...

explanations.A: This is on how many days her bag was equal to 8kg. We want the number of days the mass of her bag was LESS THAN 8kg...
explanations.B: When the bag's mass is 7 1/4 kg and 7 2/4kg it is less than 8kg, this occurs on 3 days as there are 3 crosses.
explanations.C: This is on how many days her bag was more than 8kg. We want the number of days the mass of her bag was LESS THAN 8kg...
explanations.D: This would be on how many school days the mass of her bag was 8 kg or less. We just want the number of days it was less than 8kg...

explanations.A: There are two crosses above 6 1/4 kg, three above 6 1/2 kg, and one above 6 3/4 kg. Altogether this is 6 crosses, meaning the mass was over 6kg on 6 days.
explanations.B: This would be on how many school days the mass of her bag was 6kg or more. We just want the number of days it was more than 6kg...
explanations.C: This is on how many days her bag was equal to 6kg. We want the number of days the mass of her bag was MORE than 6kg...
explanations.D: This is on how many days her bag was less than 6kg. We want the number of days the mass of her bag was MORE than 6kg...
